DUSSELDORF, Germany (AP) â€” Russian President Vladimir Putin on Friday signed a bill introducing a prison sentence of up to 15 years for those spreading information that goes against the Russian governmentâ€™s narrative on the war in Ukraine.

The bill criminalizing the intentional spreading of what Russia deems to be â€œfakeâ€ reports about the war was quickly rubber-stamped by both houses of the Kremlin-controlled parliament earlier in the day.

Background: Russian State Duma passes bill to impose lengthy prison sentences on those reporting news on Ukraine invasion that doesnâ€™t match Putin party line

Russian authorities have repeatedly decried reports of Russian military setbacks or civilian deaths in Ukraine as â€œfakeâ€ news. State media outlets refer to Russiaâ€™s invasion of Ukraine as a â€œspecial military operationâ€ rather than a â€œwarâ€ or an â€œinvasion.â€

Vyacheslav Volodin, the speaker of the lower house of Russian parliament, said the new measure â€œwill force those who lied and made statements discrediting our armed forces to bear very grave punishment.â€

â€œI want everyone to understand, and for society to understand, that we are doing this to protect our soldiers and officers, and to protect the truth,â€ he added.

From the archives: â€˜It wasnâ€™t Putin who invaded Ukraineâ€™: How state media in Russia are depicting the ongoing attack

Plus: Firehose of disinformation foreseen by Biden administration appears to have been uncorked amid Russiaâ€™s invasion of Ukraine

The new law envisages sentences of up to three years or fines for spreading what authorities deem to be false news about the military, but the maximum punishment rises to 15 years for cases deemed to have led to â€œsevere consequences.â€

Also Friday, the state communications watchdog, Roskomnadzor, blocked Facebook and five foreign media organizations based abroad that publish news in Russian in a sweeping action to establish even tighter controls over the information about the Russian invasion of Ukraine reaching ordinary Russians.

It was later reported that Meta Platforms FB, -2.24% unit Facebookâ€™s social-media archrival, Twitter TWTR, -1.68% , was also being blocked in Russia.





Roskomnadzor, blocked Facebook, citing its alleged â€œdiscriminationâ€ of the Russian media and state information resources. The agency said in a statement that the restrictions introduced by Facebook owner Meta on the Russian news channel RT and other state-controlled media violate the Russian law.

See: Premiers of Baltic states and Poland call on U.S. social-media giants to stem flow of Russian disinformation

Also: Meta restricts access to Russian state media across EU to quell misinformation

And: Ukraineâ€™s Zelensky calls on Russian troops to ignore Kremlin propaganda, lay down their arms and save their own lives

Nick Clegg, Metaâ€™s president of global affairs, said in a tweet in response to Russiaâ€™s action that â€œmillions of ordinary Russians will find themselves cut off from reliable information, deprived of their everyday ways of connecting with family and friends and silenced from speaking out.â€

â€œWe will continue to do everything we can to restore our services so they remain available to people to safely and securely express themselves and organize for action,â€ Clegg added.

The Russian media blocks also affected five foreign media organizations based abroad which publish news in Russian. They included the BBC, the U.S. government-funded Voice of America and Radio Free Europe/Radio Liberty, German broadcaster Deutsche Welle and Latvia-based website Meduza. Together, they are among the most influential and often critical foreign media publishing in Russian.

From the archives (January 2021): Biden administration moves swiftly to return government-run overseas broadcasters to pre-Trump posture

Also read: Russian independent radio station Ekho Moskvy taken off air by Putin regime over coverage of Ukraine attack

Roskomnadzor said those media had published â€œfalse informationâ€ on subjects including â€œthe methods of carrying out combat activities (attacks on civilians, strikes on civil infrastructure), the numbers of losses of the Russian Federation Armed Forces and victims among the civilian population.â€

The BBC said Friday it was temporarily stopping the work of all its journalists and support staff in Russia while it assessed the implications of the new law. BBC Director-General Tim Davie said the legislation â€œappears to criminalize the process of independent journalism.â€

â€œThe safety of our staff is paramount and we are not prepared to expose them to the risk of criminal prosecution simply for doing their jobs,â€ he said.

Davie said the BBCâ€™s Russian-language news service would continue to operate from outside Russia.

Earlier in the day, the BBC posted instructions on Twitter about how Russian readers could work around the block by using apps or the â€œdark web.â€

See: BBC benching its reporters in Russia after Duma passes bill restricting Ukraine coverage

â€œAccess to accurate, independent information is a fundamental human right which should not be denied to the people of Russia, millions of whom rely on BBC News every week. We will continue our efforts to make BBC News available in Russia, and across the rest of the world,â€ the BBC said.

Earlier this week the BBC said it was bringing back shortwave radio transmission to Ukraine and parts of Russia so people can listen to its programs with basic equipment.

Some well-known media outlets within Russia have chosen to close rather than face heavy restrictions on what they can report. News website Znak announced it was closing Friday morning, shortly after the parliament approved the draft bill. On Thursday, Russiaâ€™s top independent radio station Ekho Moskvy was closed and independent TV station Dozdh suspended operations after receiving a threat of closure from the authorities.

The authorities also pressed ahead Friday a sweeping effort to target human rights organizations.

Authorities on Friday raided the offices of Memorial, one of Russiaâ€™s oldest and most prominent human rights organizations. According to Memorial members, police didnâ€™t provide any explanation and there were no warnings.

â€œThe police refused to let me and the lawyer in without explanation, and when I tried not to let in the reinforcement officers who arrived in bulletproof vests and masks, they threatened to use force if I did not let them in,â€ the chairman of International Memorial Yan Rachinsky said. â€œThis is the level of justice today in the capital of Russia.â€

Another leading human-rights group, the Civic Assistance, also saw its Moscow office raided on Friday.

MarketWatch contributed.
